FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Simmons Foods, Inc.

SWC Processing

10700 S State HWY 43 N

Southwest City, MO 64863



RE:  Executive Summary, (RMP)



1.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY POLICIES.



At Simmons Foods, Inc. we utilize anhydrous ammonia which is considered hazardous by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  The properties which make ammonia valuable as a refrigerant also necessitate certain safety precautions.  Simmons Foods, Inc. strives to protect all its valuable resources and assets, both personnel and property.  We live and have families in this community.  We want to prevent exposure to all our personnel as well as nearby members of our community, existing natural resources, and the surrounding environment.  It is our policy to comply with all Federal, State, and local regulations.  Through continual, accurate training and various safety devices and procedures, we work to minimize potential releases.



Our emergency response program has specific procedures for accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia as well as other emergencies.  We work in conjunction with the Southwest City Volunteer Fire Department and the McDonald County Local Emergency Planning Committee to prepare for necessary notification of all affected neighbors.



2.    THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED.



The primary purpose of our facility is the processing of poultry products.  We utilize anhydrous ammonia as the primary means for refrigeration, cooling and freezing.  An outside company is used to fill our main receiver tanks.  Piping then carries the ammonia to the needed refrigeration, cooling or freezing units.  Access to the site is restricted to facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.



3.    THE WORST CASE AND ALTERNATE CASE RELEASE SCENARIOA?S.



This location has prepared a worst case release and an alternate case release scenario by using the RMPComp air dispersion modeling software. We also used MARPLOT for mapping the dista

nce to the toxic end point. 



Documentation of these scenarios is kept of file for review upon request.



4.    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY.



In the five years preceding the submittal of this RMP, this facility has not had any accidental releases of ammonia which have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



5.    THE RMP MANAGEMENT PROGRAM.



The management of the RMP program will be handled by Keith Hirsch, Facility Operations Manager.  Keith Hirsch will administrate in conjunction with the Simmons Foods, Inc. management and personnel.  Other entities or organizations that will be coordinated with include the McDonald County LEPC and the Southwest City Fire Department and Hazardous Materials Response Team.



6.    THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS.



In accordance with RMP regulations, the general accidental release prevention program for this facilityA?s ammonia refrigeration system is comprised of the following components: process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, operator training, procedures for maintaining mechanical integrity,  procedures for managing system changes, pre-start up safety review procedures, procedures for investigating release incidents, and hot work permit protocols.  This program was developed with the participation of the affected employees, and will be periodically audited for compliance required by the RMP regulations.  In addition, the facility has in place procedures for notifying contractors and their employee of the hazards of the system.  Chemical specific prevention steps are included within the program, including engineering and administration controls designed to prevent and minimize accidental releases.







7.    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM.



Simmons Foods, Inc. emergency response program is based on the OSHA

requirements for Emergency Action Plans (29 CFR 1910.38 and 1910.119) and Hazwoper (29 CFR 1910.120).  We have trained employees for emergency response and maintain a written emergency response plan.  This plan is coordinated with the McDonald County LEPC, and Southwest City Volunter Fire Department.  We conduct drills for implementation of the emergency response plan.
